- Coma = acute impairment of alertness + impairment of consciousness


- Demonstrated by the patient's lack of response despite verbal, tactile or painful stimulation (increasing intensity).


- Vigilance = opening of the eyes and presence of an old-sleep rhythm (spontaneous alternation between opening and closing of the eyes, or after stimulation).


- Consciousness = presence of interaction with the environment. By definition, eye tracking is sufficient to classify the patient as conscious, even if they are classified as minimally conscious.


- NB: you have to be alert to be conscious; you can be alert without being conscious (vegetative state).

question.title: What is the definition of consciousness in a comatose patient?
question.description: According to the provided text, what is the minimum criterion for a patient to be classified as conscious?

option_a.title: Presence of spontaneous alternation between opening and closing of the eyes
option_a.description: A patient who meets this criterion is considered conscious.

option_b.title: Eye tracking and presence of an old-sleep rhythm
option_b.description: A patient who meets this criterion is considered conscious.

option_c.title: Spontaneous movement and verbal response to stimulation
option_c.description: A patient who meets this criterion is considered conscious.

option_d.title: Presence of an old-sleep rhythm and ability to track objects
option_d.description: A patient who meets this criterion is considered conscious.
